verses.text: Then the high priest asked, 'Are these things so?'
verses.comment: Stephen is put on trial before the religious leaders. The high priest's role points to spiritual authority and a divinely-ordained priesthood (see Leviticus 21:10).

verses.text: Stephen replied: 'Brothers and fathers, listen. The God of glory appeared to our father Abraham when he was in Mesopotamia, before he lived in Haran,
verses.comment: Stephen addresses his audience with respect and recalls Abraham’s calling, emphasizing obedience to God's initiative. This demonstrates the importance of listening to God’s chosen revelations and the continuity of God’s plan.

verses.text: 'Leave your country and your relatives,' God said, 'and go to the land I will show you.'
verses.comment: Stephen quotes God’s command to Abraham. The emphasis is on faith and obedience even when God’s purposes are not yet revealed.

verses.text: So Abraham left the land of the Chaldeans and lived in Haran. After his father died, God moved him from there to this land where you now live.
verses.comment: See Abraham’s trust in God leading him step by step, an example of responding to divine guidance ahead of full understanding.

verses.text: He did not give him any inheritance in it, not even a foot’s length, but promised to give it to him as a possession, and to his descendants after him, though he had no child.
verses.comment: This highlights the importance of trusting God’s promises, which are not always fulfilled immediately. God's faithfulness surpasses human limitations.

verses.text: And God spoke in this way: that Abraham’s descendants would be strangers in a foreign land, and that they would be enslaved and mistreated for four hundred years.
verses.comment: God’s foreknowledge is shown here, as well as a prophecy fulfilled later in Egypt. Such prophecies demonstrate the authority and continuity of divine revelation.

verses.text: 'But I will judge the nation that they serve,' said God, 'and after that they will come out and worship Me in this place.'
verses.comment: Judgment and deliverance are central themes. Worship 'in this place' points to a sanctified worship, a foreshadowing of the chosen place meant for God’s people.

verses.text: And He gave him the covenant of circumcision. So Abraham became the father of Isaac, and circumcised him on the eighth day; and Isaac became the father of Jacob, and Jacob of the twelve patriarchs.
verses.comment: The covenant sign of circumcision foreshadows how the people of God are marked, implying the importance of visible signs and sacraments within the faith community.

verses.text: The patriarchs, moved by jealousy, sold Joseph into Egypt; but God was with him,
verses.comment: Despite persecution and betrayal, God remains faithful to His servants. Joseph's suffering prefigures Christ's own betrayal and suffering.

verses.text: and rescued him out of all his troubles, and gave him favor and wisdom before Pharaoh, king of Egypt, who made him ruler over Egypt and over all his household.
verses.comment: God exalts the humble and brings good out of suffering for His plan. Joseph's role as ruler foreshadows the later authority bestowed on witnesses to God’s will.

verses.text: Now a famine came over all Egypt and Canaan, bringing great affliction, and our fathers found no food.
verses.comment: Physical needs often serve as the background for God’s intervention and plan to preserve His people.

verses.text: But when Jacob heard that there was grain in Egypt, he sent our fathers there the first time.
verses.comment: Even in hardship, God provides through the means of human cooperation and response to His prompts.

verses.text: On their second visit, Joseph made himself known to his brothers, and Pharaoh learned of Joseph’s family.
verses.comment: Recognition and reconciliation are highlighted. Shows God's plan at work even when hidden at first.

verses.text: Then Joseph sent for his father Jacob and all his relatives, seventy-five in all.
verses.comment: Different ancient traditions count the family differently (see Gen. 46:27). Stephen would have used the Septuagint number. It’s another example of faithful interpretation with respect to contemporary understandings.

verses.text: So Jacob went down to Egypt, and he died there, he and our fathers.
verses.comment: They journeyed according to God’s plan, dying outside the Promised Land, awaiting God’s promise.

verses.text: And their bodies were carried back to Shechem and laid in the tomb that Abraham had bought for a sum of silver from the sons of Hamor in Shechem.
verses.comment: Returning the patriarchs to the promised land signifies faith in resurrection and completion of God’s covenant.

verses.text: As the time of the promise drew near, which God had sworn to Abraham, the people increased and multiplied in Egypt
verses.comment: The faithfulness of God to His promises is evident in the growth of His people, even in exile.

verses.text: until another king, who did not know Joseph, arose over Egypt.
verses.comment: Stephen summarizes the shift to oppression and suffering, which forms the background for Moses’ story.

verses.text: He dealt deceitfully with our nation, and oppressed our fathers, forcing them to abandon their infants so that they would not survive.
verses.comment: Describes the injustice Israel faced. God is attentive to the suffering of His covenant people.

verses.text: At this time Moses was born, and was beautiful in God’s sight. He was cared for in his father’s house for three months.
verses.comment: Moses’ birth and preservation prefigure the providential care given to God’s chosen leaders throughout history.

verses.text: When he was abandoned, Pharaoh’s daughter took him and raised him as her own son.
verses.comment: Displays God using even unlikely circumstances and foreigners to further His redemptive plan.

verses.text: So Moses was instructed in all the wisdom of the Egyptians, and he was powerful in his words and deeds.
verses.comment: Moses’ education and abilities prepare him for leadership. Preparation and formation are key for those set apart by God.

verses.text: When he was forty years old, it came into his heart to visit his brothers, the children of Israel.
verses.comment: A sign of Moses’ solidarity with his people, a key trait in faithful leaders.

verses.text: Seeing one of them being wronged, he defended him and avenged him by striking down the Egyptian.
verses.comment: Moses’ righteous anger against injustice foreshadows Christ's zeal for justice, though his action is not yet guided by full divine command.

verses.text: He expected that his brothers would understand that God was giving them deliverance by his hand, but they did not understand.
verses.comment: Rejection of God’s chosen deliverer is a recurring theme, foreshadowing the rejection of Jesus.

verses.text: The next day he appeared to them as they were quarreling and tried to reconcile them, saying, 'Men, you are brothers; why do you wrong each other?'
verses.comment: Moses as peace-maker echoes Christ’s ministry of reconciliation (cf. Matt. 5:9).

verses.text: But the man who was wronging his neighbor pushed him away, saying, 'Who made you a ruler and a judge over us?'
verses.comment: This anticipates later resistance to divinely established leadership structures.

verses.text: 'Do you want to kill me as you killed the Egyptian yesterday?'
verses.comment: The rejection of Moses by his own people becomes a central point in Stephen’s speech, later mirrored in the rejection of Christ.

verses.text: At this remark, Moses fled and became a sojourner in the land of Midian, where he became the father of two sons.
verses.comment: Being a 'sojourner' highlights the motif of pilgrimage, exile, and spiritual preparation for greater work.

verses.text: When forty years had passed, an angel appeared to him in the wilderness of Mount Sinai, in the flame of a burning bush.
verses.comment: God’s revelation comes in preparation, through a sacred encounter. Theophanies (divine appearances) reveal God’s initiative.

verses.text: When Moses saw it, he was amazed at the sight. As he drew near to look, the voice of the Lord came to him:
verses.comment: Direct communication from the Lord solidifies the reality of personal encounter with God in sacred moments.

verses.text: 'I am the God of your fathers, the God of Abraham and of Isaac and of Jacob.' Moses trembled and did not dare to look.
verses.comment: Identifying God as the God of the patriarchs roots the present in God’s covenant faithfulness. Sacred fear is appropriate before the Holy.

verses.text: Then the Lord said to him, 'Take off the sandals from your feet, for the place where you are standing is holy ground.'
verses.comment: God’s presence consecrates places for divine use—implications later for the idea of sacred places and objects.

verses.text: 'I have surely seen the oppression of My people who are in Egypt, and I have heard their groaning, and I have come down to deliver them. Now come, I will send you to Egypt.'
verses.comment: God sends deliverers as a sign of continuing care, echoing the mission of Christ as Redeemer and the sending of Church leaders.

verses.text: This Moses, whom they rejected, saying, 'Who made you a ruler and a judge?'—this man God sent both as ruler and redeemer, by the hand of the angel who appeared to him in the bush.
verses.comment: Moses as ruler and redeemer prefigures the ultimate redeemer, Christ, who is also rejected and then vindicated. The mediation of angels links to spiritual authority and heavenly worship.

verses.text: He led them out, performing wonders and signs in Egypt, at the Red Sea, and in the wilderness for forty years.
verses.comment: Miracles and signs confirm divine authority, as do Christ’s miracles in the New Testament.

verses.text: This is the Moses who said to the Israelites, 'God will raise up for you a prophet like me from among your brothers.'
verses.comment: This prophecy is fulfilled in Jesus. 'Prophet like me' is a typological connection between Moses and Jesus, who mediates a new covenant.

verses.text: This is the one who was in the congregation in the wilderness with the angel who spoke to him on Mount Sinai, and with our fathers. He received living words to give to us.
verses.comment: Moses prefigures the mediator of the new covenant. The 'living words' are the revealed law, a forerunner to later authoritative teaching in the Church.

verses.text: But our fathers refused to obey him; they rejected him, and in their hearts they turned back to Egypt,
verses.comment: Rejection of Moses parallels the later rejection of Jesus and divine authority in general; shows the need for faithfulness.

verses.text: saying to Aaron, 'Make for us gods who will go before us. As for this Moses who led us out of Egypt, we don’t know what has happened to him.'
verses.comment: Moses’ absence led to apostasy. Shows human need for visible leadership and guidance.

verses.text: And they made a calf in those days, and offered a sacrifice to the idol, and rejoiced in the works of their hands.
verses.comment: Idolatry is condemned. This contrasts true worship with false, foreshadowing later eucharistic theology centering on a true sacrifice.

verses.text: But God turned away and gave them over to worship the host of heaven, as it is written in the book of the Prophets: 'Did you bring to Me slain beasts and offerings for forty years in the wilderness, O house of Israel?'
verses.comment: God judges by permitting people to choose. It lays the groundwork for understanding the seriousness of liturgical faithfulness.

verses.text: You took up the tent of Moloch and the star of your god Rephan, the images that you made to worship; so I will send you away beyond Babylon.'
verses.comment: Refers to later exile for idolatry. The discipline is lengthy but rooted in eventual restoration—a faith preserved through visible, faithful leadership.

verses.text: Our fathers had the tent of testimony in the wilderness, just as He who spoke to Moses directed him to make it, according to the pattern that he had seen.
verses.comment: Tabernacle constructed after a heavenly pattern. God’s worship has a divine blueprint.

verses.text: Our fathers in turn brought it in with Joshua when they took possession of the nations driven out by God before our fathers. So it was until the days of David,
verses.comment: Continuity from Moses to David: divine worship is passed down and evolves, not abolished, under God’s guidance.

verses.text: who found favor in God’s sight and asked to find a dwelling place for the God of Jacob.
verses.comment: David’s desire for a temple points to the desire for God’s permanent presence among His people.

verses.text: But it was Solomon who built a house for Him.
verses.comment: Solomon builds the temple, showing the culmination of the desire for a dwelling for God in Israel.

verses.text: Yet the Most High does not dwell in houses made by human hands, as the prophet says:
verses.comment: God transcends all earthly buildings. True worship is spiritual and universal, yet includes visible expression as guided by God.

verses.text: 'Heaven is My throne, and the earth is My footstool. What kind of house will you build for Me,' says the Lord, 'or what is the place of My rest?'
verses.comment: Scripture shows that the presence of God is not confined to a structure; the worshiping community itself becomes His dwelling (cf. Eph. 2:21-22).

verses.text: 'Did not My hand make all these things?'
verses.comment: God reminds us that all creation belongs to Him; humility is the only proper attitude before the Creator.

verses.text: You stiff-necked people, uncircumcised in heart and ears! You always resist the Holy Spirit. As your fathers did, so do you.
verses.comment: Stephen indicts the leaders for resisting the Spirit—connecting rejection of God’s chosen mediators throughout history with present unbelief. True openness is needed.

verses.text: Which of the prophets did your fathers not persecute? They killed those who foretold the coming of the Righteous One, whom you have now betrayed and murdered,
verses.comment: 'The Righteous One' is a title for the Messiah, fulfilled in Jesus. Stephen ties together Christ’s identity as fulfillment of prophecy and Israel’s ongoing resistance to God’s messengers.

verses.text: you who received the law as delivered by angels and did not keep it.
verses.comment: Angels as mediators emphasizes the heavenly source of the Law—yet points to a greater fulfillment in the New Covenant.

verses.text: Now when they heard these things, they were cut to the heart, and they gnashed their teeth at him.
verses.comment: A hard-hearted reaction to spiritual truth—a warning against resisting God's convicting word.

verses.text: But he, full of the Holy Spirit, looked up steadily into heaven, and saw the glory of God, and Jesus standing at the right hand of God.
verses.comment: Stephen is the first to see Jesus glorified, confirming his vision through Scripture. Christ’s standing position indicates both authority and advocacy for His Church (cf. Rom. 8:34; Heb. 7:25).

verses.text: And he said, 'Behold, I see the heavens opened, and the Son of Man standing at the right hand of God.'
verses.comment: 'Son of Man' references Daniel 7, indicating Christ's divine authority and glorified humanity. The heavens opened reveal direct access to God through Christ.

verses.text: But they cried out with a loud voice, stopped their ears, and rushed together against him.
verses.comment: Rejecting the message by blocking their ears—willful blindness is condemned throughout Scripture (cf. Jer. 6:10).

verses.text: Then they cast him out of the city and stoned him. And the witnesses laid down their garments at the feet of a young man named Saul.
verses.comment: Saul (later Paul) is introduced as a witness, showing God's sovereignty in calling even persecutors to become leaders of His Church.

verses.text: As they were stoning Stephen, he called out, 'Lord Jesus, receive my spirit.'
verses.comment: Stephen imitates Jesus in his last words (cf. Luke 23:46), displaying the highest form of discipleship. He appeals directly to Jesus, indicating Christ’s divinity.

verses.text: Then he knelt down and cried with a loud voice, 'Lord, do not hold this sin against them.' And after saying this, he fell asleep.
verses.comment: 'Fell asleep' is a euphemism for death, later used for Christian saints. Stephen’s forgiveness follows Christ’s example (see Luke 23:34). His final prayer hints at confident hope in life after death.
